questiontext.text: A polyfunctional substrate contains an aryl bromide, a terminal alkyne, and an allylic acetate (all present in the same molecule). The goal is to form (i) an aryl–alkyne bond and (ii) an allylic substitution product, while minimizing cross-reactivity and controlling selectivity. Which strategy is most defensible based on the mechanistic “decision tree” logic of coupling-method selection and the distinct intermediate types involved?

generalfeedback.text: Sonogashira forms aryl–alkyne bonds via Pd oxidative addition to aryl/vinyl halides and (commonly) Cu-assisted alkynyl transmetalation, whereas Tsuji–Trost proceeds via a π-allyl–Pd intermediate from an allylic substrate and then nucleophilic attack, so the two transformations are mechanistically distinct and lend themselves to planned sequencing with selective conditions. The route-planning emphasis in the unit is to choose coupling methods based on functional group tolerance/compatibility and to use strategy/sequence control in multi-coupling settings rather than assuming one coupling universally suppresses another. The other options mix unrelated steps (Suzuki not directly required here), misattribute β-hydride elimination to allylic regioselection, or invoke McMurry which is carbonyl–carbonyl coupling and does not “stabilize” an allylic acetate in the stated way.

answer.text: Perform Tsuji–Trost first (π-allyl–Pd chemistry), then Sonogashira, because allylic substitution and alkyne coupling use fundamentally different Pd intermediates and can be sequenced with orthogonal condition control
Perform Sonogashira first, then Suzuki, because boronic acids prevent allylic substitution side reactions
Perform Heck first on the aryl bromide, then Tsuji–Trost, because β-hydride elimination improves allylic regioselectivity
Perform McMurry first to “lock in” the allylic acetate as an alkene, then do Sonogashira

questiontext.text: Two allylic substrates are subjected to Pd-catalyzed allylic substitution with the same nucleophile; one substrate gives mainly linear product, the other gives mainly branched product after changing only the ligand environment. Which statement best explains how ligand choice can flip regioselectivity in this reaction family?

generalfeedback.text: Tsuji–Trost chemistry proceeds through a π-allyl palladium intermediate, and the unit highlights steric/electronic effects plus ligand-induced control as key determinants of linear vs branched regioselectivity (and also enantioselectivity). Oxidative addition is not the step that “chooses” linear vs branched, and β-hydride elimination is a Heck-related feature rather than the defining selectivity control element here.

answer.text: Ligands control whether oxidative addition occurs, which directly determines linear vs branched products
Ligands alter steric/electronic environment of the π-allyl palladium intermediate, biasing nucleophilic attack toward one terminus (linear vs branched)
Ligands change the nucleophile from hard to soft, which changes the reaction into Suzuki coupling
Ligands suppress π-allyl formation and instead force β-hydride elimination

questiontext.text: A synthesis plan uses ring-closing metathesis (RCM) to form a macrocycle from a diene, but the major outcome is oligomerization/polymerization instead of cyclization. Which factor is most consistent with the unit’s treatment of ring-size/macrocyclization issues and metathesis selectivity challenges?

generalfeedback.text: The unit explicitly connects RCM outcomes to ring-size effects and macrocyclization considerations and discusses selectivity issues (including competing pathways) in metathesis applications. Metallacyclobutane formation is fundamental to metathesis for a broad range of alkenes (not limited by “six carbons”), Cu(I) is not the defining co-catalyst for metathesis, and Pd is not the catalyst family highlighted for the metathesis mechanism in this syllabus segment.

answer.text: Macrocyclization competes unfavorably with intermolecular metathesis events unless conditions/strategy favor intramolecular closure
The metallacyclobutane intermediate cannot form for dienes longer than six carbons
RCM requires copper(I) co-catalyst to avoid oligomerization
Using Pd instead of Ru is the standard fix for macrocyclization failure

questiontext.text: A student proposes replacing Suzuki coupling with Stille coupling in a late-stage synthesis of a heterocycle-containing intermediate because “Stille is always greener and more scalable.” Which response best evaluates this claim using the unit’s emphasis on green chemistry/practicality and reagent trade-offs?

generalfeedback.text: The unit explicitly flags toxicity and environmental concerns of organotin reagents in Stille coupling and frames coupling-method choice as a trade-off among scope, functional group tolerance, and practical/green considerations rather than a universal ranking. Suzuki is often chosen for practical reasons including reagent convenience, and the presence of oxidative addition is not itself a sufficient “green vs not green” discriminator because many Pd couplings share that step.

answer.text: The claim is correct because organotin reagents are environmentally benign and universally preferred
The claim is incorrect because Stille involves organotin reagents with known toxicity/environmental concerns, so “greener” is not automatic despite potential scope advantages
The claim is correct because Suzuki requires oxidative addition, which generates toxic halide waste
The claim is incorrect because Stille cannot couple heterocycles, while Suzuki can

questiontext.text: In designing a multi-step route that uses two different Pd-catalyzed C–C forming reactions, a chemist wants to minimize unintended reaction at an “extra” electrophilic site (e.g., a second halide) until later in the synthesis. Which conceptual approach most directly matches the unit’s guidance on multi-coupling strategy and selectivity optimization?

generalfeedback.text: The unit’s integration section emphasizes multi-coupling strategies, decision-based method selection, and selectivity optimization including chemoselectivity/regioselectivity in polyfunctional substrates, explicitly pointing to sequential/temporal control and protecting-group/compatibility planning. The other options contradict the stated need for controlled sequencing and overgeneralize catalyst swaps or metathesis scope beyond what is justified for diverse electrophilic sites. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/0d13af76-414f-4c3b-8d8c-2f6b625d3637/organic_unit_05.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/710f5898-842c-4d82-ad4a-29c3aa7a6003/organic_unit_06.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/bbb354c7-10b6-4c64-93aa-f65f58d9fb78/organic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/f41187d8-4c1f-42a8-b69c-1b08ca48bd7f/organic_unit_04.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/d56907a9-060e-4d86-bddd-81839e191ded/organic_unit_08.txt)

answer.text: Run all couplings in one pot without regard to timing, because Pd cycles are self-selective
Use temporal control (sequential couplings) and compatibility-aware choices (method/conditions/protecting strategies) to direct chemoselectivity among multiple reactive sites
Replace Pd with Ti(III) to eliminate chemoselectivity problems
Switch to only metathesis because it ignores functional groups

questiontext.text: In a generic Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling, which step forms the new C–C bond?

generalfeedback.text: In palladium cross-coupling, oxidative addition inserts Pd into the C–X bond of the electrophile, transmetalation transfers the nucleophilic carbon to Pd, and reductive elimination couples the two carbons to form the C–C bond; β-hydride elimination does not form C–C bonds in these cycles.

questiontext.text: Which coupling employs boronic acids or boronic esters as the nucleophilic partners?

generalfeedback.text: Suzuki–Miyaura coupling uniquely uses organoboron reagents (boronic acids/esters) with a base to promote transmetalation, offering high functional group tolerance; Stille uses organotin, Negishi uses organozinc, and Kumada uses organomagnesium reagents.

questiontext.text: The Heck reaction typically couples an aryl or vinyl halide with:

generalfeedback.text: The Heck reaction is a Pd-catalyzed aryl/vinyl–alkene coupling proceeding via oxidative addition, alkene insertion, and β-hydride elimination to give substituted alkenes; alkynes are characteristic of Sonogashira, while organozinc and boronic acids belong to Negishi and Suzuki couplings, respectively.

questiontext.text: Which coupling classically requires a copper(I) co-catalyst to activate terminal alkynes?

generalfeedback.text: Sonogashira coupling forms aryl–alkynyl bonds by deprotonating terminal alkynes, often via a Cu(I) alkynide intermediate that transmetalates to Pd; Hiyama uses organosilanes with fluoride, Stille uses organotin reagents, and Tsuji–Trost is an allylic substitution, not an alkyne coupling.

questiontext.text: Which statement best describes oxidative addition in cross-coupling?

generalfeedback.text: Oxidative addition converts Pd(0) to Pd(II) by inserting into the carbon–halide (or pseudohalide) bond; reductive elimination forms the C–C bond, transmetalation transfers the organic group from the nucleophile (e.g., B, Zn, Sn), and base activation is specifically relevant to Suzuki transmetalation.

answer.text: Pd(0) inserts into a C–X bond to give Pd(II)
Pd(II) eliminates to form a C–C bond
Transfer of R group from M to Pd center

questiontext.text: Which organometallic coupling partner is noted for toxicity concerns despite broad scope?

generalfeedback.text: Stille coupling leverages organotin reagents that are effective and versatile but raise environmental and health concerns; organoboron reagents are low-toxicity and user-friendly, organozinc are more reactive yet compatible, and organosilanes are relatively benign but require fluoride activation.

questiontext.text: In the Hiyama coupling, efficient transmetalation commonly requires:

generalfeedback.text: Hiyama coupling involves organosilanes that are activated by fluoride to facilitate Si–C to Pd transmetalation under mild conditions; copper(I) is typical of Sonogashira, strong base alone is insufficient for Hiyama, and photocatalysts are not inherent to this classical method.

questiontext.text: Which reaction is an example of palladium-catalyzed allylic substitution rather than cross-coupling?

generalfeedback.text: Tsuji–Trost proceeds via a π-allyl–Pd intermediate, enabling nucleophilic substitution at allylic positions with control over regio- and enantioselectivity; Kumada, Negishi, and Suzuki are cross-couplings forming C–C bonds via transmetalation from Mg, Zn, and B reagents respectively.

questiontext.text: Olefin metathesis proceeds through which key intermediate?

generalfeedback.text: Ruthenium alkylidene catalysts mediate olefin metathesis via a [2+2] cycloaddition to a metallacyclobutane followed by cycloreversion; π-allyl Pd belongs to Tsuji–Trost, Pd(IV) is not the canonical intermediate here, and Cu(I) acetylide is associated with Sonogashira.

questiontext.text: The McMurry reaction couples two carbonyl compounds to form:

generalfeedback.text: Low-valent titanium species generated in McMurry conditions couple two carbonyls through a pinacol-like intermediate and reductive elimination to give an alkene; the net transformation is reductive olefination, not diol formation (that is the intermediate state) nor full reduction to alkanes or formation of alkynes. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/0d13af76-414f-4c3b-8d8c-2f6b625d3637/organic_unit_05.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/f41187d8-4c1f-42a8-b69c-1b08ca48bd7f/organic_unit_04.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/710f5898-842c-4d82-ad4a-29c3aa7a6003/organic_unit_06.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/37bed375-4faf-4477-a010-e72ec0280345/organic_unit_10.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/bbb354c7-10b6-4c64-93aa-f65f58d9fb78/organic_unit_07.txt)

answer.text: A diol via pinacol coupling only

questiontext.text: In a Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling, an aryl iodide and an aryl chloride are reacted separately under identical conditions with the same Pd(0)/phosphine catalyst. Which statement best predicts the relative rate of oxidative addition?

generalfeedback.text: Oxidative addition of Pd(0) into a C–X bond is strongly influenced by the nature of the halide, and aryl iodides are generally more reactive than aryl chlorides toward oxidative addition because the C–I bond is weaker and iodide is a better leaving group in this context. The other choices ignore the standard reactivity trend emphasized for cross-coupling electrophiles and incorrectly attribute the rate to sterics or “bond polarization only” without considering oxidative addition feasibility.

answer.text: Aryl chloride undergoes oxidative addition faster due to stronger C–Cl bond polarization
Aryl iodide undergoes oxidative addition faster due to better leaving group ability of iodide
Both proceed at the same rate because oxidative addition depends only on palladium, not halide
Aryl chloride undergoes oxidative addition faster because chloride is smaller and less steric

questiontext.text: A student wants to form a biaryl bond using a coupling that typically requires a base to enable transmetalation. Which reagent pair best matches this requirement?

generalfeedback.text: Suzuki–Miyaura coupling uses boronic acids/esters and commonly relies on hydroxide/alkoxide base to facilitate transmetalation from boron to palladium. Organotin partners correspond to Stille coupling (not base-driven in the same defining way), organozinc corresponds to Negishi coupling, and Grignard corresponds to Kumada coupling and is typically less functionally tolerant.

questiontext.text: In the Heck reaction, the formation of an alkene product is closely associated with which elementary step after migratory insertion?

generalfeedback.text: The Heck mechanism features oxidative addition, alkene insertion, and then β-hydride elimination to generate the substituted alkene (commonly giving E-alkene) and a Pd–H species. Reductive elimination is the C–C bond-forming step in many cross-couplings, but the Heck product alkene arises via β-hydride elimination after insertion rather than a final reductive elimination to create the alkene framework.

questiontext.text: A terminal alkyne is coupled with an aryl bromide to give an aryl-alkyne under Pd catalysis. Which additional component most directly explains the commonly used co-catalyst role in this transformation?

generalfeedback.text: In Sonogashira coupling, Cu(I) commonly forms a copper acetylide from the terminal alkyne, enabling efficient transfer of the alkynyl group to palladium during transmetalation. Fluoride activation is characteristic of Hiyama coupling (organosilanes), while strong-acid vinyl cation pathways and Ti(III) radical reductions are not the defining mechanistic features described for Sonogashira in this unit.

answer.text: Copper(I) helps generate a metal acetylide that transfers the alkynyl group during transmetalation
Fluoride activates the alkyne by forming a pentavalent silicon ate complex
Strong acid protonates the alkyne to form a vinyl cation intermediate
Titanium(III) reduces the aryl bromide to an aryl radical

questiontext.text: A chemist must choose among Negishi, Kumada, and Hiyama couplings for a substrate bearing a base-sensitive functional group. Which choice is most consistent with selecting the coupling that is described as operating under comparatively mild activation (via fluoride) and improved functional group tolerance?

generalfeedback.text: Hiyama coupling uses organosilane partners and is described as fluoride-mediated in transmetalation/activation, often allowing mild conditions and good functional group tolerance. Kumada uses organomagnesium/organometallic partners that are typically more reactive and less tolerant, Negishi uses organozinc (not fluoride activation as a defining feature here), and Stille still proceeds via transmetalation (and is not among the three options being compared in the prompt).

answer.text: Kumada, because organomagnesium reagents are mild and tolerate many groups
Negishi, because organozinc reagents require fluoride activation
Hiyama, because organosilanes can be fluoride-activated and are used under mild conditions

questiontext.text: A palladium-catalyzed allylic substitution proceeds via a π-allyl palladium intermediate and can give either linear or branched products depending on steric/electronic effects and ligand choice. Which named reaction best matches this description?

generalfeedback.text: Tsuji–Trost reactions are defined by formation of a π-allyl–Pd intermediate followed by nucleophilic attack, with regioselectivity (linear vs branched) and enantioselectivity influenced by substrate and ligands. Heck and Suzuki are cross-coupling families with different key intermediates/steps, while McMurry is a low-valent titanium-mediated carbonyl coupling to alkenes.

questiontext.text: A student observes formation of an unwanted “biaryl byproduct” when performing Suzuki coupling with a boronic acid. Which adjustment is most directly targeted at the stated special-case issue in Suzuki reactions?

generalfeedback.text: The unit explicitly highlights “boronic acid homocoupling prevention” as a special consideration in Suzuki coupling and links optimization to ligand and base selection. Fluoride activation is tied to Hiyama, titanium reagents are tied to McMurry, and copper(I) co-catalysis is characteristic of Sonogashira rather than Suzuki.

answer.text: Choose conditions that prevent boronic acid homocoupling (optimize ligand/base)
Replace Pd with low-valent titanium reagent
Use copper(I) to generate an alkynide intermediate

questiontext.text: A ring-closing metathesis (RCM) is planned to convert a diene into a cyclic alkene. Which catalyst family is most directly associated with this transformation in the syllabus unit?

generalfeedback.text: Olefin metathesis in this unit is described as proceeding with ruthenium-based catalysts (including common Grubbs/Hoveyda families) and includes RCM as a key application. Palladium-phosphine cycles describe cross-coupling; copper acetylide chemistry is Sonogashira; and Ti(III) conditions describe McMurry carbonyl coupling.

answer.text: Palladium-phosphine catalysts used for oxidative addition/transmetalation cycles
Copper(I) acetylide catalysts used for terminal alkyne coupling
Titanium(III) reagents used for carbonyl–carbonyl coupling

questiontext.text: A vinyl halide is coupled with an alkene under Heck conditions. The product is predominantly an E-alkene. Which mechanistic feature best rationalizes the typical E-alkene outcome in this reaction family?

generalfeedback.text: The Heck reaction is described with syn addition (insertion) and a β-hydride elimination pathway, and this sequence is associated with formation of E-alkene products in typical cases. π-allyl palladium intermediates define Tsuji–Trost chemistry, transmetalation is not the defining step for Heck (it uses alkene insertion instead), and radical-chain framing is not the core mechanism emphasized here.

answer.text: The reaction proceeds through a π-allyl palladium intermediate that enforces E geometry
Syn addition followed by β-hydride elimination commonly leads to E-alkene formation
The base-catalyzed transmetalation step sets the E/Z ratio
The reaction is a radical chain process that selectively forms E-alkenes

questiontext.text: Two aldehydes are subjected to low-valent titanium conditions to form an alkene. Which statement best captures the reaction’s key mechanistic logic at the 2-mark (intermediate) level?

generalfeedback.text: McMurry coupling is described as a titanium(III)/low-valent titanium-mediated carbonyl coupling where carbonyl reduction and coupling give a pinacol-like intermediate (often represented as a Ti–O–Ti bridged species) that leads to net deoxygenative olefination. The other options incorrectly import Pd cross-coupling steps (oxidative addition/transmetalation/reductive elimination), Suzuki logic, or π-allyl chemistry from Tsuji–Trost. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/0d13af76-414f-4c3b-8d8c-2f6b625d3637/organic_unit_05.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/eecdaa56-93b9-4e87-bc04-9974af604151/inorganic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/f41187d8-4c1f-42a8-b69c-1b08ca48bd7f/organic_unit_04.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/bbb354c7-10b6-4c64-93aa-f65f58d9fb78/organic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/d56907a9-060e-4d86-bddd-81839e191ded/organic_unit_08.txt)

answer.text: Aldehydes first undergo oxidative addition to titanium, then transmetalation, then reductive elimination
Carbonyls are reduced to ketyl-like species that couple (pinacol-type intermediate) and ultimately deoxygenate to an alkene
Aldehydes undergo base-promoted transmetalation from boron, then reductive elimination
Aldehydes form a π-allyl complex that is attacked by a nucleophile
